required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Correlation Between Body Weight and Foot Progression Angle in Adolescents
clinical_study.official_title: Correlation Between Body Weight and Foot Progression Angle in Adolescents

lead_sponsor.agency: Delta University for Science and Technology

clinical_study.source: Delta University for Science and Technology

brief_summary.textblock: Obesity is associated with functional decline , altered spatiotemporal gait parameters (e.g. lower gait speed, shorter strides, and increased step width), and a significantly higher metabolic cost of walking compared to people with normal body weight. Obesity also negatively affects balance control.This study will investigate foot progression angle in adolescents related to their weight and category classification based on the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) growth charts.

primary_outcome.measure: foot progression angle for healthy group
primary_outcome.description: participants in healthy group will be assessed for foot progression angle (FPA). The FPA is defined as the angle made by the long axis of the foot from the heel to 2nd metatarsal and the line of progression of gait

primary_outcome.measure: foot progression angle for overweight group
primary_outcome.description: participants in overweight group will be assessed for foot progression angle (FPA). The FPA is defined as the angle made by the long axis of the foot from the heel to 2nd metatarsal and the line of progression of gait.

primary_outcome.measure: foot progression angle for obese group
primary_outcome.description: participants in obese group will be assessed for foot progression angle (FPA). The FPA is defined as the angle made by the long axis of the foot from the heel to 2nd metatarsal and the line of progression of gait.

primary_outcome.measure: foot progression angle for underweight group
primary_outcome.description: participants in underweight group will be assessed for foot progression angle (FPA). The FPA is defined as the angle made by the long axis of the foot from the heel to 2nd metatarsal and the line of progression of gait.

arm_group.description: Children in this group will be healthy category according to CDC chart which ranged from BMI-for-age 5th to 85th percentiles
Children in this group will be overweight category according to CDC chart which ranged from BMI-for-age 85th to 95th percentiles
Children in this group will be obese category according to CDC chart which ranged from BMI-for-age > 95th percentiles
Children in this group will be underweight category according to CDC chart ranged from BMI-for-age < 5th percentiles

study_pop.textblock: Two hundred healthy non-athletic children from both sexes will participate in this study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All children have normal stature for age percentile according to CDC chart.
- The sample will include both sex and will be divided in to 4 groups according to the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) growth charts.
- All children are normal &perform all activities of daily living
- They were able to understand and follow verbal commands and instructions included in the testing procedures.
Exclusion criteria:
- All of them could be part of recreational activities in their public schools but no competitive sports. Children who participated in any regular sport activities involving the lower extremities will be excluded.
- None of them had any surgical intervention in the lower extremities.
- None of them had any history of musculoskeletal deformities or neuromuscular disorders.
- They had neither visual, auditory defect.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Delta University for Science and Technology
responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant. Professor of physical therapy, Department of Physical Therapy for Pediatrics
